original: Description / This is modern manual for the worship of the goddess Durgā / It was written by Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Goswāmī a Bengali brahmin who was professsor of the Sanskrit College of the Vidyādharmavarddhinī Pāṭhaśālā in Agra where he taught Yajurveda / He was also an expert in ritual / The manual was published in with a commentary bhāṣātikā by his son Ghanaśyāma Gosvaāmī /
analyzed: description this is modern manual for the worship of the goddess durgā it was written by lakṣmīnārāyaṇa gosvāmī a bengali brahmin who was professsor of the sanskrit college of the vidyādharmavarddhinī pāṭhaśālā in agra where he taught yajurveda he was also an expert in ritual the manual was published in with a commentary bhāṣātikā by his son ghanaśyāma gosvaāmī
translated: Description: This is a modern manual for the worship of the Goddess Durga. It was written by Lakshminarayana Goswami, a Bengali Brahmin who was a professor of the Sanskrit College of the Vidyadharmarvardhini Pathshala in Agra where he taught the Yajur Veda. He was also an expert in ritual. The manual was published in 1911 with a commentary called Bhashatika by his son Ghanashyama Goswami.

translated: The rite is extensively described with all the details necessary to perform it completely just by following the instructions given in the book. The full rite, which is quite extensive, is primarily performed during the period of Navarātri in combination, as usual, with the recitation of the Durgāsaptaśatī drawn from the Mārkaṇḍeyapurāṇa. The layout is very clear and systematic, allowing anyone with a basic knowledge of ritual performance and Sanskrit to perform the rites. It has therefore been a very popular work throughout North India.

analyzed: samārabhet mantrī kulluka ādyā yathā vidhiḥ pṛthvī dhyānam
translated: The meditation on the earth is as follows: The earth is of five colors,🔽variegated, endowed with various fragrances,

original: rajaścitrā nānā gaṃdha samanvitā // puṣpa prakara saṃkīrṇā ghaṃtā cāmara
analyzed: rajaścitrā nānā gaṃdha samanvitā puṣpa prakara saṃkīrṇā
translated: filled with heaps of flowers, with bells and chowries,

original: bhūṣitā // bālārka sadṛśīramyā manaḥ saṃtoṣa kāriṇī // evaṃ🔽bhūmiṃsamāśritya pūjayetparameśvarīm // parikīrtitā // iti viśuddheśvara
analyzed: bhūṣitā bāla arka sadṛśīramyā manaḥ saṃtoṣa kāriṇī evam  bhūmiṃsam āśritya pūjayet parameśvarīm parikīrtitā iti viśuddha īśvara
translated: Adorned, beautiful like the rising sun, pleasing to the mind. Thus🔽having resorted to the ground, one should worship the Supreme Goddess.

analyzed: tantre
translated: It is proclaimed thus in the Vishuddeshwara Tantra.

analyzed: p
translated: Thus.

original: iti kullukāṃmūrddhni vicintya ācamanaṃ kuryāt mūlaṃ ātma tatvāya svāhā //
analyzed: iti kullukāṃ mūrddhni vicintya ācamanam kuryāt mūlam ātma tatvāya svāhā
translated: Having contemplated the Kullika on the head, one should perform the Ācamana (ritualistic sipping of water) with the Mūla mantra: Om, to the Ātma tattva (principle of self), Svāhā (obeisance).

original: mūlaṃ vidyā tatvāya svāhā // // mūlaṃ śiva tatvāya svāhā // //🔽ityācamya // mūlena itidviroṣṭāvunmṛjya // mūlena iti karaṃ prakṣālya jalena
analyzed: mūlam vidyā tatvāya svāhā    mūlam śiva tatvāya svāhā  iti ācamya mūlena iti dvis oṣṭau unmṛjya mūlena iti karam prakṣālya jalena
translated: Om, to the Vidyā tattva (principle of knowledge), Svāhā. Om, to the Śiva tattva (principle of Śiva), Svāhā.

original: sapta chidrāṇyupaspṛśet // oṃ mahākālyai namaḥ āsye // oṃ mahā
analyzed: sapta chidrāṇi upaspṛśet om mahākālyai namaḥ āsye om mahā
translated: Having performed the Ācamana thus, one should wipe the lips twice with the Mūla mantra. Having washed the hands with the Mūla mantra, one should touch the seven apertures with water.

analyzed: lakṣmyai namaḥ om mahāsarasvatyai namaḥ nasoḥ om nandajāyai namaḥ
translated: Om, salutations to Mahākālī in the mouth. Om, salutations to Mahālakṣmī. Om, salutations to Mahāsarasvatī in the nose. Om, salutations to Nandajā.

original: oṃ rakta dantikāyai namaḥ netrayoḥ // oṃ śākaṃbharyai namaḥ // oṃ
analyzed: om rakta dantikāyai namaḥ netrayoḥ om śākaṃbharyai namaḥ om
translated: Om, salutations to Raktadaṃtikā in the eyes. Om, salutations to Śākaṃbharī. Om,

original: durgāyainamaḥ śrotrayoḥ // oṃ bhīmāyai namaḥ nābhau // oṃ bhrāmaryai
analyzed: durgāyai namaḥ śrotrayoḥ om bhīmāyai namaḥ nābhau om bhrāmaryai
translated: salutations to Durgā in the ears. Om, salutations to Bhīmā in the navel. Om, salutations to Bhramari

original: namaḥ urasi // oṃ aṣṭādaśa bhujāyai namaḥ śirasi // oṃ aṣṭabhujāyai
analyzed: namaḥ urasi om aṣṭādaśa bhujāyai namaḥ śirasi om aṣṭa bhujāyai
translated: in the chest. Om, salutations to the one with eighteen arms on the head. Om, salutations to the one with eight arms.

original: namaḥ // oṃ daśa bhujāyai namaḥ bhujayoḥ // evaṃ aṅgāni spṛṣṭvā //
analyzed: namaḥ om daśa bhujāyai namaḥ bhujayoḥ evam aṅgāni spṛṣṭvā
translated: Salutations. Om, salutations to the ten-armed one, to the arms. Having touched the limbs thus,

original: hu haṃ hīṃ astrāya phaṭ // anena digbandhanaṃ kṛtvā prāṇāyāmaṃ
analyzed: hu haṃ hīṃ astrāya phaṭ anena digbandhanam kṛtvā prāṇāyāmam
translated: Hu, Ham, Him, to the weapon, Phat. Having bound the directions with this, one should perform the breath control.

original: kuryāt // yathā mūlā dhāre manaḥ saṃyojya dakṣiṇāṃguṣṭhena dakṣiṇa
analyzed: kuryāt yathā mūlā dhāre manaḥ saṃyojya dakṣiṇa aṃguṣṭhena dakṣiṇa
translated: Having united the mind with the root support, holding the right nostril with the right thumb, one should fill the air through the left nostril,

original: nāsā puṭaṃ dhṛtvā praṇavaṃ mūlādyabījaṃ vā ṣoḍaśa vāraṃ japan
analyzed: nāsā puṭam dhṛtvā praṇavam mūla ādya bījam vā ṣoḍaśa vāram japan
translated: repeating the Pranava or the root seed mantra sixteen times.

original: vāma nāsayā vāyumāpūrya kaniṣṭhānāmikābhyāṃ vāma nāsāpuṭaṃ
analyzed: vāma nāsayā vāyum āpūrya kaniṣṭhā anāmikābhyām vāma nāsāpuṭam
translated: Holding the left nostril with the ring finger and little finger,

analyzed: dhṛtvā catuḥṣaṣṭhi vāram japan vāyum staṃbhayitvā
translated: one should stop the air by repeating it sixty-four times.

analyzed: dakṣiṇa nāsayā dvātriṃśat vāram japan recayet iti ekaḥ punar tena eva
translated: Exhaling through the right nostril, repeating it thirty-two times, is one method. Again,

original: mānane dakṣiṇa nāsāpuṭaṃ prapūrya kumbhayitvā vāmena recayediti
analyzed: mānane nāsā puṭam prapūrya kumbhayitvā vāmena recayet iti
translated: filling the right nostril with that, holding the breath, and exhaling through the left is

original: dvitīyaḥ // punarādyavattṛtīyaḥ mūlena cedekena pūrakaṃ caturbhiḥ
analyzed: dvitīyaḥ punar ādya vat tṛtīyaḥ mūlena ced ekena pūrakam caturbhiḥ

analyzed: kumbhakam dvābhyām recakam iti evam prāṇāyāmam vidhāya
translated: the holding of the breath is with two, and the exhalation is with two. Having thus performed the breath control,

analyzed: nīlataṃtre kullukān ca na jānāti mahāmaṃtram japet naraḥ paṃcatvam jāyate
translated: in the Nīlataṇḍra: One who does not know the Kulkuka, a man who repeats the great mantra, will attain the state of five.

analyzed: tasya bhavet kullukām ca sarva yajña phalam labhet
translated: Or he may be invincible. By wearing the Kulkuka on the head, one obtains the fruits of all sacrifices.

translated: One should wear the Kulkuka on the head, written on a birch bark leaf. At the royal gate and in the assembly, one becomes victorious,

analyzed: bhavati dhruvam na anyaḥ vicāraḥ sarvatra virūpākṣasya sammataḥ kullukā

analyzed: varjita ipuṃsām ajñāna upasthitiḥ bhavet mama pūjā sadā mama
translated: For men devoid of the Kulkuka, ignorance persists. My worship is always futile,

analyzed: jānāti ca yaḥ mūḍhaḥ kullukām caṃḍikām japet yāvajjīvam tu japtavyam na  siddhi ati kadācana
translated: The foolish one who does not know should perform the japa of the Kulkuka Chandika. The japa should be performed throughout life,

analyzed: p

analyzed: bhūtaśuddhau sarvāsu vāhya pūjāsu antar pūjā vidhīyate

analyzed: antar pūjā maheśāni vāhya koṭi phalam labhet   /

analyzed: bhūtaśuddhi lipi nyāsau vināyaḥ tu prapūjayet
translated: Without the purification of the elements and the nyasa of the letters, one should worship the obstacles.

analyzed: phalam dadyāt abhaktyā pūjane yathā
translated: It gives contrary fruits, like worship without devotion.

analyzed: bhūta śuddhim kuryāt
translated: One should perform the purification of the elements.

analyzed: yathā hūkāraṇa mūlādhārāt kuṇḍalinīm utthāpya jīvātmanā saṃyojya
translated: As in the Hūṃkāra, having raised Kuṇḍalinī from the root chakra, and united it with the individual soul,

analyzed: haṃsaḥ iti mantreṇa paramātma nivilāpayet tatas pāda ādi jānu paryantam

analyzed: sthitām pṛthvīm jānu ādi nābhi paryantam sthitām apsu pravilāpya tāḥ

original: prakṛtau tāṃ ca brahmaṇi vilāpayet // tataḥ puruṣa nibhaṃ pāpamanādi
analyzed: prakṛtau tām ca brahmaṇi vilāpayet tatas puruṣa nibham pāpam anādi

analyzed: bhava saṃcitam brahmahatyā śiraḥ skandham bhuja dvayam

analyzed: pātakam

analyzed: rakta śmaśru vilocanam khaḍga carma dharam pāpam aṃguṣṭha
translated: with red beard and eyes, holding a sword and shield, the sin, the size of a thumb,

analyzed: parimāṇakam adhomukham kṛṣṇa varṇam vāma kukṣau viciṃtayet iti

analyzed: raṃ iti vāram āvṛtena bījena kumbhaka prayogena mūlādhāre
translated: and with the seed syllable RAM repeated sixty-four times, by the practice of breath retention, uniting in the root chakra,

original: saṃyojya raṃ saṃcitya sapāpaṃ dehaṃ bhasmāntaṃ saṃdahya punaryamiti
analyzed: saṃyojya raṃ saṃcitya sa pāpam deham bhasma antam saṃdahya punar yaṃ iti
translated: contemplating RAM, burning the sinful body to ashes, again with the seed syllable YAM,

analyzed: bījena dvātriṃśat vāra māvṛtena dakṣiṇa nāsayā pāpapuruṣa bhasma  recayet tatas vamiti bīja japāt lalāṭe candrāt mātṛkāḥ varṇa mayīm amṛta
translated: repeated thirty-two times, one should exhale the sinful person's ashes through the right nostril.🔽Then, by the repetition of the seed syllable VAM, letting fall a rain of nectar in the form of the letters of the Mātṛkā alphabet from the moon in the forehead,

original: vṛṣṭiṃ nipātya bhasmāplāvya nyāsakrameṇāvayavān niṣpādya // lamiti

analyzed: paramātmanaḥ prakṛtim tasyāḥ
translated: the nature of the supreme self, the principle of Mahat of that,

original: tato'haṃkāraṃ tasmādākāśaṃ tato vāyuṃ tasmāttejastasmājjalaṃ🔽tasmātpṛthivīṃ nigamya sva sva sthāne sthāpayitvā brahmaraṃdhrastha
analyzed: tatas ahaṃkāram tasmāt ākāśam tatas vāyum tasmāt tejaḥ tasmāt jalam  tasmāt pṛthivīm nigamya sva sva sthāne sthāpayitvā brahmaraṃdhra stha
translated: then ego, from that space, from that air, from that fire, from that water,

translated: The coiled Kundalini in the form of a bud, having brought Kundalini to the lotus of the heart,🔽having placed Kundalini in the root chakra, one should visualize one's body as fit for the worship of the deity, free from all sins. Thus is the purification of the elements.

analyzed: caṇḍikāyāḥ prāṇān pratiṣṭhāpayet
translated: Having performed such purification of the elements, one should establish the life-breaths of Chandika in one's own body.

analyzed: atha yāmala ukta bhūtaśuddhiḥ prārabhyate
translated: Now the purification of the elements as described in the Yamala is begun.

analyzed: om sūryaḥ somaḥ yamaḥ kālaḥ saṃdhyā bhūtāni paṃca

analyzed: bho deva prākṛtam cittam pāpa ākrāṃtam abhūt mama
translated: O Lord, my natural mind has been afflicted by sin.

original: tanniḥsāraya cittānme pāpaṃ testu namo namaḥ // //🔽iti prārthya svadakṣiṇabhāge oṃ guṃgurubhyo namaḥ // svavāma bhāge oṃ gaṃ
analyzed: tat niḥsāraya cittāt me pāpam teḥ tu namaḥ namaḥ  iti prārthya sva dakṣiṇa bhāge om guṃ gurubhyaḥ namaḥ sva vāma bhāge om gaṃ
translated: Remove that sin from my mind. May there be well-being. Salutations again and again.

analyzed: gaṇapataye namaḥ om kṣaṃ kṣetrapālāya namaḥ pṛṣṭhe iti natvā

original: bhūtaśuddhiṃ kuryāt // tathā ca kumbhaka prāṇāyāme mūlādhārāt kuṇḍalanīṃ
analyzed: bhūtaśuddhim kuryāt tathā ca kumbhaka prāṇāyāme mūlādhārāt

analyzed: para devatām visa taṃtu nibhām samutthāpya brahmaraṃdhra gatān ramṛtvā
translated: Having raised the deity of others, resembling a hundred threads, and having united with the one in the aperture of Brahma,

original: hṛdayasthaṃ jīvaṃ pradīpa kalikākāraṃ gṛhītvā suṣumṇāmārgeṇa
analyzed: hṛdaya stham jīvam pradīpa kalikā ākāram gṛhītvā suṣumṇā mārgeṇa
translated: Having taken the soul residing in the heart, in the form of a lamp wick, through the suṣumnā channel,

analyzed: brahmaraṃdhram gatvā haṃsaḥ sohaḥ iti maṃtreṇa jīvam brahmaṇi saṃyojayet
translated: Having gone to the aperture of Brahma, one should unite the soul with Brahman through the mantra Hamsa Soham.

original: tataḥ pādādi jānuparyantaṃ catuṣkoṇaṃ vajralāṃchitaṃ svarṇavarṇaṃ🔽pṛtvhīmaṃḍalaṃ oṃ laṃ iti bhūvījāḍhyaṃ smaret // //
analyzed: tatas pāda ādi jānu paryantam catuṣkoṇam vajra lāṃchitam svarṇa varṇam  om laṃ iti bhū vīja āḍhyam smaret  /
translated: Then, from the feet up to the knees, one should meditate on the earth mandala, which is square, marked with a vajra, golden in color,🔽And endowed with the seed syllable Om Lam.

analyzed: jānu ādi nābhi paryantam arddhacandra ākāram padma dvaya aṅkitam śveta varṇam
translated: From the knees up to the navel, one should meditate on the water mandala, which is in the shape of a half-moon, marked with two lotuses, white in color,

original: apāṃsthānaṃ somamaṃḍalaṃ oṃ vaṃ iti varuṇabījāḍhyaṃ smaret // //
analyzed: apām sthānam soma maṇḍalam om vaṃ iti varuṇa bīja āḍhyam smaret  /
translated: And endowed with the seed syllable Om Vam of Varuṇa.

analyzed: nābhi ādi hṛdaya paryantam trikoṇam svastika aṃkitam rakta varṇam agni maṃḍalam
translated: From the navel up to the heart, one should meditate on the fire mandala, which is triangular, marked with a svastika, red in color,

original: oṃ ra iti vahni vījāḍhyaṃ smaret // //
analyzed: om raḥ iti vahni vīja āḍhyam smaret  /
translated: And endowed with the seed syllable Om Ra of Agni.
From the heart up to the middle of the eyebrows, one should meditate on the air mandala, which is circular, marked with six dots, smoky in color,

original: vāyumaṃḍalaṃ oṃ ya iti vāyu bījāḍhyaṃ smaret // //
